reviewText: 'Where Do We Go From Here?' has been missing for years, but this 20th Century Fox film offers a great many plus factors that earn it an unique spot in 40's musicals.  One cannot deny the importance of a work that involves the musical talents of Kurt Weill teaming with Ira Gershwin!!!  (Yes, I know that Rodgers & Hart's 'They Met  in argentina' is a mess, but this one is not).  The story, back and forth in time,, doesn't quite work, but the songs take up the rhythm... and Joan Leslie is pert and delightful.  June Haver looks and dances well.  Fred MacMurray may not seem quite at home as the storyline goes back and forth and then back again.  And Gregory Ratoff does not have the light touch for the venture.... Still.... Gershwin-Weill-Leslie-Technicolor-some laughs-dances.  Glad it is around.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A cute, if not great comedy, and with a master of the genre like Fred MacMurray it probably comes across a lot better than it actually is? Fred's funny, June Haver is gorgeous, and several years later, she married Fred MacMurray, and they lived happilly till death did them part! Nice picture and colour, and a pleasant enough little bit of escapism from the nasty real world for 77 minutes at least!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you like Haver or McMurray there is enough here to get by, but the music mostly is pretty forgettable and the dancing so-so.  The story line does take a few comic turns with nice cameos by the likes of Alan Mowbry, Herman Bing, and Anthony Quinn, but the musical aspect is mostly a little forced and despite the contribution of Ira Gershwin most of the score is weak.  If it was done as a pure comedy with more expansion on the roles of McMurray, Haver, and Leslie it might have been a little better.  Still it is an okay film but not great by any means.  The print is also a little dark at times for those concerned with quality.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Where Do We Go From Here?" is a forgotten 20th musical that was ahead of it's time.  It got lost in the shuffle and deserves to be re-discovered.  Released at the end of WWII the film caught the studio off-guard and movie audiences, geared to "back-stage" musicals, somewhat perplexed.  Obviously intended for WWII audiences it was suddenly dated.  "Morale", a production number sung by June Haver, was cut from release prints but is seen here (lucky for movie fans).  The score, written by Ira Gershwin and Kurt Weill, ranged from ballads to swing to a very funny operatic sequence spoofing the voyage of Christoper Columbus. Holding it all together is the marvelously talented Fred Mac Murray whose comedy timing and vocalizing (yes, it's him) are immpeccable.  Very few could have carried this off as well.  The print bears the TV trade mark not the 20th spotlight original. The color is murky but gets by. It's NOT Technicolor lacking the bright sharpness of the three-strip process. A print shown on Cinemax was better and marked the TV "color premiere" of the film.  Although dated into WWII "Where Do We Go From Here?" is a forgotten pleasure that comes as a bit of a surprise but remains refreshing and original.  It could use more songs in the second half but, that aside, it's a fun-filled musical journey that's great to see again.
summary: Fred Mac Murray sings, dances and romances in this witty WWII musical
Title: N/A

reviewText: Produced at a time when we were up to our ears in WW2 it is pretty much a propaganda film about how everyone should do their best to get into the war effort.  Fred MacMurray plays Bill Morgan who wants to get into the war but is 4F (unfit) because of a hearing problem.  He finds a magic lamp and asks the genie to help him get into the war.  The genie is anything but good and Bill ends up on Columbus's ship, in the middle of the Revolutionary War, and several other places but never in WW2.  He is enamored with Lucilla Powell (played by June Haver) who ignores him and is oblivious to the charms of Sally Smith (Joan Leslie) who loves him.  Of course it all turns out OK in the end when both Bill and the genie end up in the army and Bill knows that Sally will be waiting for him.  It is pleasant enough and fun to watch but is not one of best that Fred ever made.
Title: N/A
